Despite  the  calamities  that  hit  the  country  almost  every  year,  Bangladesh‘s  economic 
2. 
growth  averaged  5.7%  per  annum  from  2000  to  2006. 2   Nonetheless,  about  half  of  the 
population  lives  below  the  national  poverty  line.  While  agriculture  engages  the  majority  of  the 
population, its share in gross domestic product (GDP) is declining. Sources of economic growth 
are shifting gradually to the higher productivity industry and services sectors. Economic growth 
has  been  fueled  largely  by  export-oriented  industries,  mainly  textiles  and  garments,  which 
accounted for about 72% of total export earnings in 2004. Other industries experiencing robust 
growth  include  leather,  leather  goods,  and  construction.  In  the  services  sector,  the  industries 
posting significant growth rates include post and telecommunication, land transport, wholesale 
and  retail  trade,  and  hotels  and  restaurants.  The  national  economy  is  buoyed  by  remittances 
from overseas Bangladeshi workers; in 2006 remittances made up the second largest source of 
foreign exchange.   
 
3. 
Economic  growth  combined  with  the  Government’s  pro-poor  policies  and  programs 
resulted  in  significant  improvement  of  some  human  development  indicators,  notably  reduced 
infant and maternal mortality, increased net school enrollment ratio, and achievement of gender 
parity in primary education. Primary enrollment has more than tripled since 1970 from 5.3 million 
to about 16.2 million in 2005, and the proportion of female enrollees has increased from 32% to 
50%. In 2005, the gross enrollment rate for primary education was about 93.7%.   
 
Over  half  of  Bangladesh’s  working  age  population  was  in  the  labor  force  in  2003. 
4. 
Women’s labor force participation has increased notably from 1996, particularly in rural areas. 
Of those employed locally, about 80% were in the informal sector and mainly self-employed or 
day  laborers;  only  14%  were  engaged  in  wage-employment.  Most  employment  is  still  in 
agriculture,  forestry,  and  related  works  (49%),  followed  by  wholesale  and  retail  trade  and 
manufacturing. Other relatively large employers include transport, storage, and communication 
service;  community,  personal  service,  and  household  sector;  construction;  and  education 
services.  More  Bangladeshis  are  seeking  employment  outside  the  country,  but  their  share  of 
employment opportunities is small. While about half of these workers are unskilled, the number 
of semiskilled and skilled workers among those deployed is growing.  
 
5.

targets  would  require  Bangladesh’s  economy  to  grow  by  7%–8%  per  annum. 3   Significant

and streamlining bureaucratic rules and regulations, and upgrading the skills and competencies 
of  human  resources.  The  national  poverty  reduction  strategy  (NPRS)  recognizes  the  potential 
contribution of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) in reducing poverty while 
supporting  economic  growth.  TVET  provides  practical  job  skills,  particularly  to  those  who

employers  in  ready-made  garments  and  textiles,  light  engineering,  and  construction  said 
workers with the required skills were not readily available in the market. The shortage is keenly 
felt  particularly  in  construction  and  light  engineering  industries, as  many  of  their  skilled 
workers have sought employment out of the country. Training for their replacements takes time 
and is costly. In the case of ready-made garments, the shortage is caused mainly by sustained 
high growth in  product  demand,  requiring  rapid expansion  of  production  capacity. Because  the 
work is labor-intensive, this entails hiring a large number of  workers within a short time, which 
often results in poaching workers from other garment firms.  

B.  

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

8. 
Need to Improve Relevance. A major weakness of the current TVET system is its lack 
of  linkage,  and  therefore  relevance,  to  the  labor  market,  i.e.,  the  formal  industry  subsectors, 
informal  self-employment  subsector,  and  international  employment.  Mismatches  between 
outputs of the TVET system and needs of employers include (i) types of trades or occupations 
where programs being offered, (ii) competencies acquired compared with industry requirements 
or  needs  for  self-employment  opportunities,  and  (iii)  practical  experience  opportunities  for 
students.  The  identification  of  courses  is  not  based  on  regular  and  systematic  assessment  of 
labor  market  needs.  Even  if  the  curricular  offerings  match  market  needs,  the  competency 
acquired  may  not  match  industry  requirements.  Employers  have  minimal  input  in  setting 
competency  standards,  determining  the  curriculum,  developing  the  testing  and  certification 
system,  and  managing  certain  training  institutions,  among  others.  There  is  wide  scope  for 
engaging industries in the TVET system, which has been barely tapped. During the consultation 
workshop  and  interviews  to  prepare  the  Project,  industry  leaders  expressed  willingness  to 
cooperate  with  TVET  system  authorities.  The  international  labor  market  is  large  but  highly 
competitive.  About  half  of  the  current  deployment  of  Bangladeshi  workers  is  made  up  of 
unskilled  laborers.  An  effective  TVET  system  can  increase  the  proportion  of  semiskilled  and 
skilled  workers  by  using  industry-recognized  and  internationally  benchmarked  competency 
standards and training systems. TVET can be made more relevant to the informal sector, too, 
by  such  activities  as  upgrading  skills  in  certain occupations.  A  number  of  NGOs  have  training 
programs catering to the informal rural subsector that are achieving high placement rates.  

9. 
Need  to  Improve  Access.  The  existing  formal  TVET  system  provides  limited 
opportunities  to  target  beneficiaries  of  the  NPRS—the  underprivileged  who  do  not  complete 

   3

class 8. Its main clientele are young adolescent males who complete class 8, can afford to stay 
more  years  in  school,  and  have  strong  white-collar  job  aspirations.  The  minimum  entry 
requirement  to  the  lowest  formal  qualifications,  basic  skill  standard  certificate  (national  skills 
standard-basic)  and  national  skill  certificate  III  (national  skills  standard  III),  which  is  class  8, 
automatically excludes the large majority who do not achieve it. Promoting female enrolment in 
nontraditional  trades  is  also  needed.  Until  very  recently,  the  lack  of  formal  recognition  by  the 
Bangladesh  Technical  Education  Board  (BTEB)  of  successful  NGO-  and  industry-delivered 
short  programs  inhibited  their  expansion.  Good  quality  competency-based  training  (CBT) 
modular  courses  offer  the  best  vehicle  for  the  TVET  system  to  reach  out  to  the  poor.  Short 
courses  would  be  more  affordable  for  trainees  than  the  2-year  SSC  (Voc)  programs.  Opening 
up TVET to the older poor by offering short CBT courses that do not necessarily require class 8 
for enrolment will increase TVET output, improve utilization of facilities, reduce unit costs, and 
make the system more relevant.  

10. 
Need  to  Improve  Quality  and  Capacity.  The  pass  rate  of  students  in  the  terminal 
external examination, conducted by BTEB, to a large extent reflects the quality of education and 
training. One of the major constraints to effective TVET delivery is the lack of trained teachers. 
The  majority  of  TVET  teachers  have  little  pedagogical  training,  including  in  CBT  delivery;  lack 
practical  skills;  and  have  little  or  no  industry  experience.  TVET  teachers  are  interested  in 
obtaining in-service training, and BTEB is considering pedagogical and technological training of 
TVET  teachers  as  a  requirement  for  the  registration  of  private  TVET  institutions.  The  country 
needs  a  TVET  teacher  training  system  that  will  provide  preservice  training  and,  more 
importantly,  will  quickly  and  effectively  provide  teacher  upgrading  and  introduce  new  curricula 
and  teaching  methodologies.  The  current  TVET  teacher  training  capacity  in  the  country  is 
limited.  The  two  public  TVET  teachers’  training  institutions,  i.e.,  Technical  Teachers  Training 
College (TTTC) in Dhaka for diploma and degree programs and Vocational Teachers Training 
Institute (VTTI) in Bogra for diploma and certificate programs, presently serve only the needs of 
Ministry of Education (MOE) TVET institutions. Their facilities need upgrading and they need to 
support non-MOE TVET institutions, including government, nongovernment, and private.  

11. 
The lack of trained teachers is compounded by the fact that the majority of private and 
some  government  TVET  institutions  have  poorly  equipped  workshops  and  laboratories,  lack 
teaching  and  training  materials,  and  have  inadequate  classrooms  and  libraries.  Consequently, 
the practical component of the curriculum is not effectively taught. The formal TVET system has 
minimal  capacity  to  meet  the  needs  of  the  labor  market.  Some  TVET  institutions  require 
substantial capital investments to increase their capacity to deliver short CBT programs.

Enhanced Relevance and Access of TVET Programs  

17. 
This  component  aims  to  enhance  the  relevance  of  training  programs  by  improving 
linkages  to  the  labor  market,  and  to  increase  access  by  developing  short  CBT  programs.  The 
Project will pilot the development of a partnership mechanism with three industries: ready-made 
garments  and  textiles,  light  engineering,  and  construction.  Their  selection  is  based  on  their 
relative  importance  to  the  economy  in  terms  of  employment  generation,  contribution  to  the 
national  output,  future  growth  prospects,  availability  of  a  formal  industry  association,  and 
interest  in  workforce  training.  The  Government  will  work  with  representatives  of  the  three 
industries and the informal sector (Appendix 5) to determine their specific skills training needs. 
The  outputs  are  (i)  partnerships  with  industry  established;  (ii)  competency  and  training 
standards  developed;  (iii)  curricula,  teacher  guides,  learning  materials  and  assessment  tools 
developed; and (iv) capacity in external competency assessment developed. 

18. 
Partnerships  with  Industry  Established.  The  Project  will  support  establishment  and 
operation  of  a  sector  working  committee  (SWC)  in  each  of  the  three  major  industries  and  the 
informal sector. Each industry SWC will comprise 8–12 technically knowledgeable experts from 
the industry’s largest member associations. The informal sector SWC will comprise experts from 
the  largest  and  most  successful  NGOs  delivering  skills  training  in  Bangladesh.  To  ensure 
coordination  and  provide  support  to  the  SWCs,  a  forum  of  skill  development  partners  will  be 
established  comprising  heads  of  the  four  SWCs,  heads  of  the  largest  industry  associations  in 
the three focus industries, and the head of the lead NGO in the informal sector SWC. The forum 
will  interact  with  the  BTEB  chairperson  and  members,  and  other  TVET  stakeholders.  SWC 
members  will  benefit  from  regional  and  national  capacity  building  activities  in  needs 
assessments,  competency  standards  development,  and  public-private  partnerships,  including 
on international experiences for relevant government officials and industry representatives.  

19. 
Competency  and  Training  Standards  Developed.  Each  SWC  will  identify  10  priority 
occupations  (40  in  total)6  for  the  development  and  dissemination  of  competency  and  training 
standards. Depending on the demand within the 40 priority occupations, the Project will support 
the development of about 100 competency standards by SWCs, most likely for basic trade and 
national  skills  standard  III.  The  standards 7   will  be  approved  by  their  respective  industry 
stakeholders and endorsed to BTEB for its approval. For the approved competency standards, 
the  SWCs,  in  coordination  with  BTEB’s  curriculum  development  committees,  will  specify  the 
training  standards  necessary  to  attain  the  competencies.  The  training  standards  will  include 
specifications for training duration, number and qualifications of instructors, teaching materials, 
and assessment method.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

60. 
Institutional  and  Sectoral.  The  Project  will  initiate  reform-oriented  activities  in  TVET 
system operation with the goal of making it more demand-driven, flexible, and oriented toward 
increasingly  serving  the  poor  and  disadvantaged.  The  pilot  model  on  public–private  sector 
collaboration  will  establish  a  linkage  between  the  TVET  authorities  and  training  providers  and 
the  formal  and  informal  labor  markets  to  minimize  the  mismatch  between  supply  and  demand 
for labor. The development and use of industry-approved or -recognized competency standards 
will introduce a new approach to the TVET system that gives more value to actual competencies 
acquired than to traditional qualifications. The revitalization of the two key TVET teacher training 
institutions  will  support  an  expanded  teacher  training  system  that  will  also  serve  private  and 
nongovernment  training  providers.  In-service  training  of  TVET  teachers  addresses  the 
immediate  need  of  TVET  providers  to  provide  untrained  teachers  with  both  pedagogical  and 
technological skills, which will contribute to improving the quality of skills training delivery.   

61. 
Social. The development of short modular CBT courses will provide greater flexibility in 
terms of duration and required students’ academic qualifications. Offering training programs not 
necessarily requiring class 8 for enrolment will expand access to the TVET system to those who 
did not complete this required grade, many of whom are poor. Upgrading the facilities of TVET 
institutions  will  improve  the  capacity  for  delivering  short,  relevant  training  programs.  Training 
workshops in selected poor communities will make training more accessible to the poor. Thus, 
the Project will open TVET institutions to a larger number of trainees in short CBT courses, most 
of whom would have been denied access because of the class 8 barrier to entry. As the training 
programs  will  be  demand-driven  and  based  on  industry-set  or  -recognized  standards, 
opportunities for employment and self-employment of trainees will improve.    

Economic.  Economic  benefits  of  the  Project  are  derived  mainly  from  (i)  increased 
62. 
access to skills training as a result of developing short, modular CBT courses; training delivery 
support; and program strengthening of selected TVET institutions; and (ii) improved relevance 
and  quality  of  skills  training  through  the  partnership  with  employers,  industry,  and  NGOs;  and 
the related revision of curricula and provision of in-service teacher training. The Project will have 
about 68,200 trainees over the five  years of implementation. After completion of their training, 
the  graduates  are  expected  to  seek  local  or  international  employment  or  be  self-employed. 
Those who will be employed locally will contribute to increased domestic production because of 

 their  skills  training  (increased  human  capital)  that  will  be  reflected  in  increased  earnings. 
Graduates  who  will  be  employed  internationally  will  bring  increased  foreign  currency 
remittances  into  the  country.  With  the  combined  efforts  to  increase  access  to  short-term  skills 
training and improve their relevance and quality,  the proportion of trainees employed from the 
Project-supported  training  programs  is  expected  to  improve  to  75%  in  2015.  Teacher  training, 
improvements  in  the  training  curricula,  and  improved  training  facilities  are  also  expected  to 
benefit students enrolled in the SSC (Voc) and HSC (Voc) programs. Although they are not the 
target  beneficiaries  of  the  Project,  improving  the  quality  of  teaching  and  practical  training  in 
vocational  subjects  is  expected  to  improve  examination  pass  rates  and  employment  rates. 
Under these projections, the economic internal rate of return is estimated at 13.9% in the base-
case scenario (Appendix 16). 

B. 

Risks and Assumptions 

63. 
The partnership model assumes the continued commitment and cooperation of the three 
partner-industry associations and NGOs in the SWC. Thus, the Project will sign memoranda of 
understanding and provide strengthening activities to SWC members. The three focus industries 
and NGOs are also eligible for training partnership assistance. Their training requirements will 
be  supported  through  the  provision  of  market-responsive  skills  training.  In  addition,  the 
concurrent  policy  development  activities  of  EC–ILO  will  reinforce  linkages  with  industry  and 
coordination  of  TVET-related  government  agencies.  The  Project’s  proposed  capacity 
development in external competency assessment for the recognition of prior learning assumes 
that the EC–ILO project activity to develop the related policy and system will be at an advanced 
stage  by  the  end  of  the  Project’s  second  year  of  implementation.  The  Project  will  closely 
coordinate with the EC–ILO project and, if any delay is experienced in that project, the services 
of  the  Project’s  specialists  in  TVET  policy  and  competency  standards  and  CBT  curriculum, 
materials  and  assessment  tools  development  can  help  prepare  the  draft  of  the  relevant  policy 
and its supporting system to facilitate the process.  

The  Project  aims  to  provide  in-service  training  to  about  4,000  untrained  teachers  from 
64. 
public  and  private  TVET  institutions.  However,  substitute  teachers  may  not  be  available  while 
the untrained teachers are on training. This will be addressed by  making the training program 
modular, short, and continuous; and scheduling teacher training when student training programs 
are not in session. The Project’s loan assurances also provide for BTEB certification of the in-
service  teacher  training.  EC–ILO  activities  in  TVET  teacher  qualifications  and  teacher 
strengthening will complement this activity.  

The  limited  scope  of  activities  in  the  two  key  TVET  teacher  training  institutions

contributed to its underutilization. The new approach to include a multiparty advisory board, in-

TECHNICAL AND VOCATIONAL EDUCATION TRAINING SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

1. 
The contribution of the technical and vocational education and training (TVET) system to 
the  supply  of  labor  relative  to  total  demand  is  minimal.  However,  the  Government  and  the 
development community recognize the potential of TVET in providing employable skills to those 
who did not and would not pass through the school system; leave the school system early; and 
need higher skills even after completing the certificate, diploma, or degree courses. However, to 
achieve the goals of the national poverty reduction strategy, many aspects of TVET need to be 
addressed: relevance, quality, and access, in particular. 

A.  

The Technical and Vocational Education Training System 

2. 
The TVET system in Bangladesh may be classified into four groups: (i) public, (ii) private 
(commercial), (iii) nongovernment organization (NGO), and, (iv) industry (managed by industry 
associations  and  industry-provided  on-the-job  training).  Each  of  these  groups  offers  a  wide 
variety  of  formal  and  nonformal  training  programs  for  various  types  of  clientele  using  different 
types of training delivery. As of school year 2004-05, formal TVET was mostly offered by about 
2,728 institutions: 180 or 7% public and 2,548 or 93% private. Of the 17,185 teachers delivering 
TVET courses, 2,939 or 17% were in public institutions and 14,246 were in private institutions. 
Of  the  241,336  total  enrolment,  20%  was  in  public  and  80%  in  private  institutions.  Between 
school years 2001/02 and 2004/05, enrolment rose by about 80%.  

3. 
Different  ministries  manage  the  public  institutions.  The  Directorate  for  Technical 
Education of the Ministry of Education (MOE) manages polytechnic and monotechnic institutes 
and  technical  schools  and  colleges;  the  Ministry  of  Labor  manages  technical  training  centers; 
the  Ministry  of  Textile  manages  textile  vocational  centers;  and  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture 
manages  agricultural  training  institutes.  The  private  institutions  are  mostly  general  secondary 
schools  offering  TVET  courses  alongside  the  general  secondary  curriculum.  While  the  private 
TVET institutions are numerous, they are mostly small with an average of about 6 teachers and 
75  students  per  institution,  compared  with  about  16  teachers  and  272  students  of  the  public 
sector,  although  their  student–teacher  ratios  are  not  too  different.  In  addition,  other  ministries 
and agencies provide nonformal TVET courses.1

4. 
Formal TVET in Bangladesh consists of three program offerings—basic, certificate, and 
diploma—with  class  (or  grade)  8  completion  a  minimum  entry  qualification.  Basic  trade  (basic 
skill  standard  certificate  or  national  skills  standard-basic)  is  a  360-hour  skills  training  course 
focusing mainly on practical skills with some theory requiring class 8 education. This is offered 
mainly at technical training centers and technical schools and colleges. The secondary school 
certificate (vocational) (SSC [Voc]) is a 2-year certificate course after class 8, and is attractive to 
students  because  of  its  equivalency  to  (i)  the  SSC  of  the  general  education  stream,  which 
provides  entry  to  higher  education;  and  (ii)    national  skills  standard  II,  which  should  provide 
entry into the world of work. National skills standard III is awarded after class 9 completion. SSC

B.  

TVET Issues  

9. 
Training Quality. The quality of education and training is generally reflected in students’ 
pass rates in BTEB’s terminal external examination. During 2000–2004, the average pass rate 
for SSC (Voc) was about 45% for both male and female students or, conversely, 55% of those 
who finish SSC (Voc) fail to pass the final examination. No data is available on the pass rate of 
HSC (Voc).  

The  low  pass  rate  for  SSC  (Voc)  can  be  attributed  to  a  number  of  factors  affecting 
10. 
instruction quality. One is the short supply of qualified TVET teachers. The sudden expansion of 
TVET  programs,  particularly  private  and  nongovernment,  has  not  been  matched  by  an  equal 
supply  of  teachers.  The  majority  of the  teachers  hired  have  no  training  on  pedagogy  and  lack 
industry  experience;  no  continuing  staff  development  is  available  to  address  this  deficiency. 
BTEB  estimates  that  about  24,000  TVET  teachers  in  the  private  sector  need  training.  In 
addition, all teachers need to be trained in the new competency-based curricula. Monitoring of 
actual teacher performance in the classrooms or workshops is lacking.  

11. 
The  capacity  of  TVET  teacher  training  institutions  is  limited.  The  Vocational  Teachers 
Training  Institute  (VTTI)  has  capacity  for  training  240  teachers  only,  and  focuses  training  on 
developing new teachers for eight trades. The Technical Teachers Training College (TTTC) has 
capacity for 80 teachers, but has been producing fewer graduates. In addition, VTTI and TTTC 
serve only the MOE TVET teachers, leaving other training providers (i.e., government, private, 
or NGO) to seek other TVET teacher training programs. The VTTI and TTTC programs need to 
be  refocused  to  provide  good  quality  training,  including  in-service  training,  to  more  TVET 
teachers  from  both  MOE-  and  non-MOE-administered  institutions.  The  facilities  of  VTTI  and 
TTTC need to be upgraded and capacity increased to provide outreach to private/NGO sector 
teachers. 

Lack  of  equipment  compounds  the  situation  in  most  training  institutions,  in  some 
12. 
instances  outdated  equipment  or  equipment  is  no  longer  operating.  In  some  schools  new 
equipment is not used as instructors have not been trained in its operation. Consequently, the 
practical component of the curriculum is not effectively taught. And since most of the institutions 
do not have a linkage with industry, the industry attachment component of the curriculum is not 
effectively implemented.  

13. 
Relevance  of  Training  Programs.  Ultimately,  the  main  measure  of  success  of  the 
TVET system if it is to significantly contribute to poverty reduction is whether its graduates find 
gainful  employment,  preferably  in  the  trade  areas  they  are  trained  for.  A  World  Bank  tracer 
study  in  2006  involving  2,302  graduates  of  public  and  private  TVET  institutions  in  2003  found 
the proportion of employed to be low (see Table A2.1). The proportion of employed was highest 
among the higher secondary certificate (vocational) (HSC [Voc]) graduates at 30%, followed by 
diploma graduates at 21%, and basic trades at 18%. These courses, however, account for only 
a small proportion of total enrollment. While the lowest proportions of employed were among the 
SSC (Voc) graduates (4%) and HSC (business management) graduates (5%), the proportions 
of their graduates pursuing higher education were the highest. This finding indicates that these 
courses appear to be catering to a clientele who can afford to pursue higher education and have 
strong  white-collar  job  aspirations;  this  is  not  consistent  with  the  objectives  of  the  national 
poverty  reduction  strategy.  Across  all  the  respondents,  only  9%  were  employed,  45%  were 
pursuing higher education and the rest were unemployed. Of those who were employed, about 
38% took less than 6 months to get a job and another 16% took up to a year. The employment 
outcomes of graduates of the public and private institutions indicated little difference.

Employers have no inputs in setting competency standards for the courses or in determining the 
curriculum. On the other hand, successful NGOs such as Under-Privileged Children’s Education 
Program,  Mirpur  Agricultural  Workshop  and  Training  School,  and  the  industry-managed 
Chittagong Skills Development Center provide models of effective TVET training programs. The 
high  employment  rate  of  the  graduates  of  their  short  and  long  courses  demonstrates  the 
importance of strong linkage with industry, which is one of their main strengths. The process of 
selecting  students  is  mainly  dependent  on  academic  marks  and  external  examinations,  and 
does not consider aptitudes and aspirations. 

15. 
The formal TVET system has minimal impact on the economy and poverty reduction; of 
the total labor force in 2003, only 0.12% received technical training from the system. One of the 
features  of  the  existing  system  is  its  focus  on  long  courses  such  as  the  SSC  (Voc)  and  HSC 
(Voc); the majority of successful graduates pursue further studies. While this helps keep young 
adolescents in school, it is an expensive route for accessing further education. Also contributing 
to  the  low  output  is  the  lack  of  formal  BTEB  recognition  of  successful  NGO  and  industry 
delivered programs such as those offered by Mirpur Agricultural Workshop and Training School, 
Caritas,  Under-Privileged  Children’s  Education  Program,  other  NGOs,  and  the  construction 
industry.  

16.

can be improved by upgrading skills in certain occupations, e.g., motorbike repair, repair of farm 
implements,  food  processing,  and  carving.  Mirpur  Agricultural  Workshop  and  Training  School, 
Bangladesh  Rural  Advancement  Committee,  and  other  successful  NGOs  have  a  number  of 
training  programs  catering  to  the  informal  rural  subsector  that  have  high  employment  rates. 
Usually  these  are  linked  with  microcredit.  Such  programs,  which  incorporate  modules  on 
entrepreneurship,  can  be  mainstreamed  by  converting  to  competency-based  training  (CBT) 
(some  already  are)  and  recognized  by  BTEB  so  that  they  can  be  scaled  up  with  Government

18. 
Governance  and  Management  Structure. The scope of the TVET subsector is much 
wider  and  more  diverse  than  generally  understood.  It  encompasses  a  large  number  of 
institutions  and  activities.  However,  its  impact  has  hardly  been  felt,  partly  because  its  various 
components  lack  a  unifying  vision  in  which  each  has  a  clearly  defined  role.  The  need  to 
rationalize  the  disparate  efforts  in  TVET  by  putting  it  under  a  single  regulatory  framework  to 
provide a unified and coherent direction was acknowledged as early as 1979 with the creation of 
the  National  Council  for  Skills  Development  and  Training  (NCSDT).  NCSDT  was  to  provide 
macro-level policy direction and other national services related to skills training, coordinate the 
efforts of different agencies involved in skills training to avoid duplication of efforts, and develop 
national  competency  standards.  Despite  the  reconstitution of  its  membership  in  1991,  NCSDT 
has  not  functioned  as  intended.  Several  factors  have  been  cited  for  its  lack  of  effectiveness, 
including  (i)  membership  is  too  big  and  difficult  to  coordinate  and  organize,  although  this  was 
partly addressed in the revised composition; (ii) many members do not have the expertise nor 
interest  in  formulating  policies  related  to  the  development  of  the  workforce  for  crafts;  (iii)  the 
NCSDT  secretariat  (Bureau  of  Manpower,  Employment  and  Training  [BMET])  does  not  have 
sufficient resources and expertise to provide the necessary support to NCSDT; and (iv) BMET 
lacks autonomy, which is needed for effective functioning as the NCSDT secretariat. 

 19.  While the initial attempt to provide a unified governance and management structure did 
not  work  as  expected,  the  need  for  it  remains  even  more  valid  and  urgent  today.  The  options 
are either to reactivate NCSDT and build on the existing legal framework, or create a completely 
new but equivalent body. Presently, MOE has overall responsibility for making policy decisions 
for  all  education,  including  technical  and  vocational  education.  The  execution  of  policies  is 
vested in two of its agencies: Directorate for Technical Education and BTEB. Under the existing 
institutional  arrangements,  a  major  component  is  conspicuously  missing—the  involvement  of 
private sector representatives, including employers, private training providers, and NGOs. They 
need to be involved not only for strategy and policy but for operations as well.   

20. 
The management of training institutions needs to be addressed. Although BMET seems 
to  be  progressing  in  decentralization,  the  overly  centralized  system  of  the  Directorate  for 
Technical  Education  does  not  allow  its  principals  to  manage.  They  do  not  have  authority  to 
decide  on  key  areas  necessary  for  effective  functioning  of  their  institutions,  e.g.,  hiring  of 
teachers, discontinuing low-demand programs,  and offering market-demanded programs. With 
clear guidelines and transparent procedures, heads of institutions should be able to select their 
teachers  for  approved  posts  and  have  the  authority  to  reward  or  penalize  depending  on 
performance.  They  should  also  be allowed  to  hire  on  a  part-time  basis.  The  authority  to  close 
down courses in trade areas with low market demand so that the resources can be channeled to 
the  more  promising  areas  should  also  be  provided.  With  respect  to  short  courses,  principals 
should  even  have  greater  authority  to  be  able  to  respond  quickly  to  market  needs.  However, 
while  autonomy  is  certainly  needed  if  management  is  to  be  accountable  for  performance, 
management’s  readiness  to  assume  greater  responsibility  must  be  considered.  Thus,  a 
continuing management development program to build management capacity is needed.

3. 
Shortcomings of the Technical and Vocational Education (TVET) System. A major 
weakness  of  the  current  TVET  system  is  the  considerable  mismatch  between  the  system’s 
outputs  and  labor  market  needs.  The  poor  condition  of  the  TVET  system  is  the  result  of  
(i)  teaching  equipment  lacking  or  malfunctioning,  (ii)  industrial  attachment  component  of  the 
curriculum rarely implemented, and the curriculum not relevant to or in demand by the industry, 
(iii)  shortage  of  qualified  teachers  with  practical  skills,  and  (iv)  focus  on  long  courses.  The 
system could greatly enhance its output by utilizing its slack capacity for the more employment-
oriented  short  courses  and  older  students.  The  overall  impact  of  the  current  TVET  system  on 
the economy is modest. A tracer study conducted by the World Bank involving 2,302 graduates 
of both public and private TVET institutions concluded that about 9% of TVET graduates were 
employed (7.3% wage-employed and 1.3% self-employed), 45% were pursuing further studies, 
and 47% were unemployed. 
 
4. 
Solutions and Project Contribution. The Project responds to the analyzed needs and 
weaknesses  of  the  TVET  system  and  aims  to  increase  its  efficiency  and  effectiveness.  It  will 
enhance the relevance of the training programs for the domestic and international labor markets 
by piloting a partnership mechanism between the key players on the supply and demand side in 
three  crucial  industry  sectors:  textiles  and  garments,  construction,  and  light  engineering.  In 
addition, a select group of nongovernment organizations (NGOs) involved in the development of 
nonfarm technical skills will be organized to address the needs for technical skills of the informal 
sector.  
 
5. 
By  upgrading  the  facilities  and  learning  materials,  through  training  of  teachers  in 
selected TVET institutions, and the provision of market-oriented short courses, the Project will 
directly  benefit  more  than  68,000  out-of-school  youths,  and  unemployed  and  underemployed 
adults who will graduate from the short competency-based training (CBT) courses of the public 
and  selected  private  institutions  during  the  5  years  of  project  implementation.  An  additional 
20,000 students are expected to take short courses after project completion. Also about 4,000 
teachers  will  directly  benefit  from  intensive  teacher  training  to  upgrade  their  technical  and 
pedagogical skills. In addition, the more than 50,000 students that attend certificate and diploma 
courses  in  these  institutions  every  year  will  indirectly  benefit  from  the  Project  as  their  courses 
will be taught by better trained teachers in better equipped facilities. This is expected to result in

raises labor productivity and is measured by the extent to which training completers earn more

A.    Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Bangladesh’s  national  poverty  reduction  strategy  (NPRS)  recognizes  the  potential  contribution  of  technical  and 
vocational education and training (TVET) to reducing poverty by providing employable skills, particularly to those who 
dropped  out  of  school  early  and  are  already  of  employable  age,  and  to  the  large  pool  of  unemployed  and 
underemployed  adults.  Skills  training  can  play  a  major  role  in  giving  people  income-earning  opportunities.  Skills 
training  in  occupational  areas  needed  by  the  labor  market  increases  the  likelihood  of  employment  and  self-
employment  of  trainees.  The  poverty  reduction  strategy  calls  for  reform  of  the  TVET  system  by  making  it  more 
market-responsive, addressing training needs of the underprivileged who do not complete class 8, collaborating with 
the private sector and nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and making its training programs more flexible in terms 
of duration, curriculum, and students’ academic qualifications, among others. 
The  Skills  Development  Project  (the  Project)  addresses  the TVET  needs  in  Bangladesh.  Focusing  mainly  on  short 
competency-based training (CBT) courses, the Project will open the formal TVET system to out-of-school youth who 
are  of  employable  age,  women,  and  unemployed  and  underemployed  adults.  It  will  extend  the  system’s  reach  to 
poverty  areas  in  collaboration  with  its  industry  and  NGO  partners.  The  Project  also  aims  to  improve  the  relevance 
and quality of TVET programs.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention  
1.  Key Issues  
Bangladesh’s formal TVET system produces a low number of training graduates and thus has a minimal impact on 
poverty reduction. The main clientele are currently the youth, about three-quarters of whom are male, who complete 
class 8 and have strong white-collar job aspirations. The class 8 barrier, the minimum entry requirement to the formal 
TVET system, automatically excludes the large majority, many of whom are poor and do not complete schooling up 
to  that  level.  The  formal  TVET  system  also  does  not  recognize  good  training  provided  by  agencies  not  under  the 
umbrella of the Ministry of Education (MOE) nor does it recognize good training provided by NGOs. The relevance 
and quality of its formal training programs are low; employment and pass rates of graduates need to be increased. 
The matching of skills training programs need to be improved to increase the employment rates of trainees.  
Training programs can be made more flexible in terms of duration (more short-term, modular training) and academic 
qualifications  (less  than  class  8),  and  made  more  relevant  by  coordinating  with  employers,  industries,  and  NGOs. 
Quality  can  also  be  improved  by  providing  training  institutions  with  the  appropriate  equipment,  a  regular  supply  of 
training materials, and TVET teachers with pedagogical and technological training. 
2. Design Features 
The Project will strengthen the capacity of the TVET systems to provide market-responsive, short-term skills training 
to more Bangladeshis. Short, modular CBT courses will be developed and will provide greater flexibility, in terms of 
duration  and  academic  qualification  requirements.  The  training  programs  will  not  necessarily  require  class  8  for 
enrolment,  which  will  expand  access  to  the  TVET  system  to  those  that  did  not  reach  this  required  level,  many  of 
whom  are  poor.  The  facilities  of  TVET  institutions  will  be  upgraded  to  expand  the  capacity  for  delivering  short, 
relevant  training  programs  and  thus  will  provide  more  space  for  students.  The  Project  will  also  establish  training 
workshops in selected poor communities, which will make training more accessible to the poor. Thus, the Project will 
open TVET institutions to a larger number of trainees in short CBT courses, most of whom would have been denied 
access  because  of  the  class  8  barrier  to  entry.  As  the  training  programs  will  be  demand-driven  and  based  on 
industry-set  or  recognized  standards,  opportunities  for  employment  and  self-employment  opportunities  of  trainees 
will improve.

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
Bangladesh made big strides in human development from the 1980s to the 2000s. In education, the primary gross 
enrollment  rate  is  over  100%  and  gender  parity  has  been  achieved  in  both  primary  and  secondary  education. 
Bangladesh’s population growth rate was halved over two decades, and infant mortality rates decreased by a quarter 
between 1989–1993 and 1995–1999. However, despite this progress, it has remained one of the poorest countries in 
the  world,  with  more  than  half  of  its  citizens  living  below  the  poverty  line.  Many  Bangladeshi  households  are 
vulnerable to income risks. In addition to shocks faced by individuals, e.g. illness, death, and dowries, the country is 
prone  to  repeated  natural  disasters  in  the  form  of  floods,  droughts,  cyclones,  and  riverbank  erosion,  which  affect 
broad segments of the population. These challenges are compounded by a population density of roughly 800 people 
per square kilometer—one of the highest in the world. Although poverty in urban areas is lower than in rural areas, it

C.  Gender and Development 

1.  Key Issues 
With  the  share  of  agriculture  in  the  national  product  decreasing,  the  employment  of  women  is  also  being 
transformed. Between 1995 and 2003, women in the labor force grew from 5.4 million to 10.3 million, and their labor 
force participation rate increased from 15.8% to 26.1%. This increase is largely fueled by the growth of the textiles 
and  ready-made  garments  industries.  Moreover,  15,000  women  took  up  international  employment  during  1991–
2000, mainly as skilled labor to the manufacturing subsector and as household maids to Middle East and Southeast 
Asian  countries.  Occupational  patterns  differ  between  men  and  women.  A  higher  proportion  of  women  (88%)  are 
employed in agriculture than men (56%). Men earn more than women. In the formal manufacturing subsector, 19% 
of  women  as  opposed  to  9%  of  men  earn  below  the  poverty  line.  Operations  of  the  ready-made  garment  industry 
depends  exclusively  on  women  workers.  In  2003,  ready-made  garments  employed  about  1.4  million  women, 
comprising 93% of its workforce. The skills needed for the job are mostly self-taught or acquired on the job. On the 
job, little investment is made by the ready-made garment  entrepreneurs or government to upgrade the skills either 
prior  to  entry  in  the  labor  force  or  during  employment.  If  the  ready-made  garment  subsector  were  to  diversify  into 
higher quality and more skill-intensive products, which is already happening in knitted garments, female workers will 
need to be upgraded. 
The experience in nonformal education activities indicate that women prefer skills that do not take them out of their 
homesteads. This results in acquiring traditional skills like poultry raising, embroidery, and tailoring. However, these 
skills cannot ensure a decent income. Employment opportunities for women were and still are limited compared with 
those  for  men.  The  factors  that  contribute  to  limited  job  opportunities  for  women  include  lack  of  social  recognition, 
lack  of  education,  lack  of  skills  training,  restrictions  on  women’s  mobility,  lower  social  status  of  women,  and  strict 
gender division of labor. Researchers  a are suggesting that the efficiency of women workers needs to be increased 
by reducing the gender gap in education and training, by introducing schemes for upgrading technology in market-
based  activities  within  households,  and  improving  the  institutional  setup  that  impacts  on  women-dominated 
industries.  
Women's lower participation in TVET contributes to their limited access to the labor market. Women are employed in 
lower-skilled  occupations,  occupying  the  lower  range  of  vocational  skills  that  are  gender-stereotypical.  Of  the  over 
241,000 students enrolled in TVET in 2005, 26% were girls, who were mostly enrolled in secondary school certificate

establishment of two more in another two divisional districts.
